abstract.p: Ossining town supervisor and retired adman John Chervokas, in honor of National Poetry Month, introduces pyrameter, new form of verse containing nine lines in which first line has one syllable and each subsequent line increases by one, so that last line has nine; example (S)

block.p: IN a previous life, he wrote the line ''Please Don't Squeeze the Charmin.''
Now John Chervokas, the retired adman who is the Ossining town supervisor, is writing poetry.
IN a previous life, he wrote the line ''Please Don't Squeeze the Charmin.''
Now John Chervokas, the retired adman who is the Ossining town supervisor, is writing poetry.

In honor of National Poetry Month, in April, he introduced what he describes as a new form of verse, the pyrameter, a nine-line poem in which the first line has one syllable and each subsequent line increasing by one syllable, so the last line has nine.

Mr. Chervokas describes the pyrameter as ''an inviting, nonthreatening verse form'' that will appeal to experienced poets and novices alike. He says it can be an effective teaching tool, helping youngsters develop both language and math skills as they evoke images in 9 lines and 45 syllables.

Readers of this section are invited to try their hands at writing pyrameters on the subject of life in Westchester or Putnam Counties. Editors will choose some of the verses to publish in a future issue.

Poems can be submitted by e-mail to westweek@nytimes.com or by mail to Westchester Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43rd Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. Authors should include their names and daytime phone number.
